Unsigned DIS Report Status : Unsigned DISCHARGE SUMMARY NAME : FLICHFENK , VINNETA UNIT NUMBER : 544-90-14 ADMISSION DATE : 03/23/1998 DISCHARGE DATE : 03/25/1998 PRINCIPAL DIAGNOSIS : Term labor . ASSOCIATED DIAGNOSIS : Anxiety disorder . PRINCIPAL PROCEDURE : Spontaneous vaginal delivery . OTHER PROCEDURES AND OPERATIONS : None . HISTORY OF PRESENT HOSPITALIZATION : The patient is a 38-year-old Gravida V , Para I-I-II-II at 39.7 weeks with contractions . She has no history of spontaneous rupture of membranes and arrived by ambulance . Her dating was by her last menstrual period of 6/9/97 with an estimated date of confinement of 03/16/98 . A 10-week ultrasound done on 8/26/97 redated her pregnancy and changed her estimated date of confinement to 03/25/98 . Her pregnancy has been followed at the A Memorial Hospital by Dr. Labor since eight weeks . Her booking blood pressure was 110/76 , and her weight gain was 24 pounds . Her pregnancy has been complicated by an abnormal triple screen with an amniocentesis on 10/10/97 revealing that mother and fetus had variations on Chromosome XIV . The pregnancy was also notable for macrosomia with an estimated fetal weight of 90% at 25 weeks and 60% at 35 weeks with an estimated fetal weight of 2818 grams . She was also noted to have borderline glucose tolerance testing on a diet , but not recording her sugars . She has a psychiatric history of anxiety and is presently on Klonopin under Dr. Labor 's management . PAST OBSTETRICAL HISTORY : Spontaneous vaginal delivery at term ; spontaneous vaginal delivery at 31 weeks with premature rupture of membranes ; therapeutic abortion at 10 weeks ; therapeutic abortion at 22 weeks . PAST MEDICAL HISTORY : Chronic back pain ; history of acute hepatitis in 1998 ; hepatitis B surface antigen negative in July of 1998 . MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION : Klonopin . ALLERGIES : No known drug allergies . PRENATAL SCREEN : Blood type A-Positive ; antibody screen negative ; hepatitis B surface antigen negative ; RPR nonreactive ; rubella immune ; PPD unknown ; glucose loading test 205 ( glucose tolerance test 100/187/192/96 ) . PHYSICAL EXAMINATION : The patient appeared very uncomfortable , blowing and working through contractions every two to three minutes . Her lungs were clear to auscultation . Her heart had a regular rate and rhythm . Abdomen : gravid ; term with a longitudinal lie and the head presenting . The estimated fetal weight was nine pounds . The fetal heart rate was in the 130s . The cervical examination was three centimeters dilated fixed , 30% effaced , and negative 1 station . Extremities : within normal limits ; 2+ deep tendon reflexes ; and no clonus . HOSPITAL COURSE AND TREATMENT : The patient was admitted to the labor and delivery suite in early labor and was monitored for fetal well being and progress . At 12:00 P.M. on 03/23/98 , her cervical examination was three centimeters dilated , 90% effaced , and negative 3 station . The fetal heart rate was in the 140s and reactive , and she was contracting every two to three minutes . She elected to use the Jacuzzi for relaxation . By 2:30 P.M. , the fetal heart tracing after a time in the hot tub was noted to have a fetal heart rate with baseline 150s and good beat to beat variation , but spontaneous deceleration to 90s for four minutes with spontaneous return back to baseline for one to two minutes . Her cervix was noted to be five centimeters , 90% effaced , and negative 2 station . There was artificial rupture of membranes for a Schick neck . An internal scalp electrode was placed , and a fetal bradycardia in the 80s to 90s for five to six minutes was noted . The patient was placed on her side , then on her hands and knees with a spontaneous return back to baseline in the 150s with good beat to beat variability . The patient continued to have deceleration to the 120s . The Anesthesia Service was consulted to place an epidural anesthetic with the decision to proceed to cesarean section for fetal distress . Scalp pH 's were done for the concerning tracing . By 3:00 P.M. , the fetal heart rate was in the 150s with good beat to beat variation and positive scalp stimulation with moderate variables to the 120s . The cervical examination was five centimeters , 90% effaced , and negative 2 station . An IUPC was placed with sterile technique by 5:00 P.M. The cervix was still noted to be five centimeters , 90% effaced , negative 2 to negative 1 station . The fetal heart rate was in the 120s with good beat to beat variation with positive accelerations and moderate variables . An amnio-infusion was started for the variables and Meconium . Pitocin augmentation was started at 5:15 P.M. once the fetal heart rate was in the 140s with positive accelerations and the amnio-infusion had begun . The patient underwent another spontaneous fetal bradycardia with a nadir in the 90s , lasting about nine minutes . The patient was repositioned and examined during this time with a vaginal examination of eight centimeters dilated , 100% effaced , and negative 2 station . The patient was begun to be moved to the operating room and then had a spontaneous return back to baseline in the 120s . A scalp pH was performed , and the patient had another deceleration to 90s while back to obtain the sample . The sample was sent at 6:00 P.M. , and the vaginal examination was now rim , negative 2 station . The patient was placed in the left lateral position with the fetal heart rate in the 120s to 130s with good beat to beat variation , and a Foley catheter was placed and the patient was prepped for cesarean section . The initial pH sample was clotted . The second sample had a pH of 7.33 . She was fully dilated and at negative 2 station . The patient began pushing once her epidural level was decreased . At 8:48 P.M. , she underwent a spontaneous vaginal delivery of a male infant with Apgar scores of 9 and 9 and a weight of eight pounds 12 ounces . The placenta was delivered status post intact with a three vessel cord . There were no episiotomies and no lacerations . The estimated blood loss was 300 cc 's . This delivery occurred under epidural anesthesia . There were no complications . The patient was transferred to the recovery room in stable condition . The patient underwent an uneventful recovery period and was transferred to the postpartum floor for routine postpartum care . She complained of transient left thigh and knee tingling and a frontal headache , both of which had resolved by postpartum day one with relief from Percocet . She elected to breast feed her baby and was receiving breast feeding support . However , by postpartum day one , she had decided to bottle feed her baby . She continued on Paxil and Klonopin for her anxiety disorder . She was discharged on 03/25/98 , postpartum day one . She refused Lord Rasouthlin Alvdale Hospital follow up for this early discharge . She has an anxiety disorder and was continued on Paxil and Klonopin , and she has a follow up appointment on 4/17/98 with her psychiatrist , Dr. Given , at A Memorial Hospital . She has a two week postpartum appointment for bilateral tubal ligation consent with Dr. Na Jesc . She was given prescriptions for Motrin , Colace , and Ferrous Sequels . The patient was discharged home in stable condition after the signs and symptoms of postpartum depression and anxiety were reviewed with her , as well as routine instructions given . CONDITION ON DISCHARGE : Stable .
